Input.threadtitle: Need help with 'common sense' understanding of probability of earthquakes
Input.posts:
Video 4.1 (Earthquake Risk) stated that there is a 40-50% probability of a magnitude 7 (or greater) earthquake occurring in the next 50 years within 50 km of San Francisco. What exactly does that probability mean? Every time I flip a coin there is a 50% chance it will come up heads. How does that relate (if at all) to the 50% probability of an earthquake? Can anyone give me a simple explanation? Help…...
Upvotes:
0
I believe this is based on geologists having studied the rocks and recorded how often those earthquakes have occurred in the past eons. They can see that the San Andreas fault has had x magnitude of earthquakes every x number of years, and the shaking is felt x strongly at x distances from the epicenter. They mix all that together and can say that since earthquakes have occurred this often over the past, they are likely to occur with the same frequency in the future. And they convert that mathematically into probabilities for the future.
Upvotes:
2
Freeman scientists have MADE this prediction after reviewing all the seismic activity and monitoring tectonic changes of the faults in this are specifically San Andrea's fault with data from the past and new . The next next earthquake will occur is just a prediction However, activity is outing on a continual basis.
Upvotes:
0
I have a good idea of the data used to make the prediction, I just have trouble relating it to everyday experience. I need a hook to hang it on. It's just to abstract. Take lighting for example: what are the odds of being hit by lighting? See this explanation (it's pretty good): http://discovertheodds.com/what-are-the-odds-of-being-struck-by-lightning/ So, let's say I going to visit San Francisco in June for 1 week. What are the odds an earthquake will occur during my visit? I'm looking for a concrete explanation - something that will connect with a high school student. I'm also interested in the other extreme: can anyone provide the equation used to make the 50% probability prediction? If I have that, I may be able to provide my own common sense explanation. This is an important issue. If people cannot connect with the problem, they may not take earthquake risk seriously.
Upvotes:
0
Well the probability that a quake will occur during a specific week is very very low. It's so low that it would not be an actionable variable in deciding whether to visit San Francisco during that specific week. So if you are wanting to connect with high school students, I would say that is not the example you'd want to use. I do not know the equation that is used to calculate the probability. The San Andreas fault in Parkfield CA has had a moderate quake every 20-22 years or so, and the southern section of the fault has a large quake every 150 years or so. Assuming the quakes will continue to occur with the same frequency, we know another like quake in those regions are now overdue. This might be a more concrete example for high school students. Here's a USGS site that talks about the San Andreas fault http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/earthq3/safaultgip.html

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Just so we don't get mixed up between the 50% and 50 years, let's imagine city XYZ for which there is a 50% chance of an earthquake of magnitude 7 or greater occurring every 100 years. That means that in every 1 year, the chance of such an earthquake occurring is 50% x 1/100 = 0.5%. Or, if you're only visiting XYZ for a week, the chance that you'll experience the event is 50% x 1/5200 wks/100yr = 0.0192%. Does that help?
